definition: A named storage location for data, e.g., x = 5
A classification of data, e.g., integer, string, or boolean
A data type for whole numbers, e.g., 42 or -7
A data type for decimal numbers, e.g., 3.14 or -0.5
A data type for text, e.g., 'Hello, World!'
A data type with two values, true or false
Data provided to a program, e.g., keyboard or mouse clicks
Data produced by a program, e.g., text on a monitor
The symbol used to store a value in a variable, e.g., =
A symbol performing operations, e.g., +, -, *, /
A combination of values and operators producing a result, e.g., 2 + 3
A complete instruction in a program, e.g., print('Hello')
A reserved word with special meaning, e.g., if, for, while
A user-defined name for variables or functions, e.g., myVariable
Non-executable text explaining code, e.g., // This is a comment
Integrated Development Environment, a tool for coding, compiling, and debugging, e.g., Visual Studio Code
A mistake in code structure, e.g., missing a semicolon
An error occurring during program execution, e.g., division by zero
A flaw in program logic causing incorrect results, e.g., wrong formula
A language translated to machine code before running, e.g., C++
A language executed line-by-line, e.g., Python
A language closer to human language, e.g., Java, Python
A language closer to machine code, e.g., Assembly
A tool to find and fix errors in code, e.g., breakpoints in an IDE
A set of instructions for a computer to execute, written in a programming language
Empty spaces or lines in code, improving readability, e.g., indentation
A naming convention combining words, e.g., myVariableName
A naming convention using underscores, e.g., my_variable_name
A fixed value that doesn’t change, e.g., const PI = 3.14
The use of spaces or tabs to structure code, improving readability
Software Development Life Cycle, a process for planning, coding, testing, and deploying software
The SDLC phase identifying what a program should do, e.g., gathering user needs
The SDLC phase planning a program’s structure, e.g., creating flowcharts
The SDLC phase writing and compiling code, e.g., coding in Python
The SDLC phase checking a program for errors, e.g., unit tests
The SDLC phase releasing a program to users, e.g., publishing an app
The SDLC phase updating and fixing a program after release
A high-level description of a program’s logic, e.g., IF input > 0 THEN print 'Positive'
A diagram representing a program’s logic, using shapes like ovals and arrows
A system to track code changes, e.g., Git for collaboration
Unauthorized copying or use of software, violating copyright laws
Protecting user data in software, e.g., secure data storage
Legal protection for software code, preventing unauthorized use
Principles guiding responsible software development, e.g., avoiding harmful code
A professional designing and coding software, e.g., developing apps
A person writing code to create programs, e.g., using Python or Java
A role testing software for reliability, e.g., finding bugs
A role combining development and operations, e.g., automating deployments
A sequence of courses leading to a job, e.g., CTE Computer Science track
Software with freely available code, e.g., Linux or Python
